courses.name: Introduction to Film Study (formerly INI115Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to film form (including style and narration), different types of films, and popular approaches to the study of cinema. Topics include: narrative cinema, documentary, avant-garde, genre, authorship, ideology, and representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Film Study (formerly INI115Y1)

courses.name: Film Cultures I: Art and Industry (formerly INI212Y1 Film History/ INI215Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the practices, theories, and debates surrounding the emergence of cinema through to the development of studio system filmmaking in the first half of the 20th Century. Topics include: film's relation to the other arts, formalist and realist traditions, technological innovations, audiences and reception, and cultural industries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Film Cultures I: Art and Industry (formerly INI212Y1 Film History/ INI215Y1)

courses.name: Horror Film (formerly INI226H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Horror film as a genre, focusing on three types of international horror: the un-dead, body horror, and the supernatural. The genre's popular appeal, affective power, unique means of producing pleasure, and current global resurgence will be emphasized. Topics include: the aesthetics of gore and violence, technologies of fear, J-Horror, new French extremity, cult fandom and paracinema, and media convergence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Horror Film (formerly INI226H1)

courses.name: Cinema and Sensation I: Action/Spectacle (formerly INI222H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Action movies cement the dominance of commercial cinema, and they largely define the contemporary era of the blockbuster and CGI effects. This course examines the narrative modes and the extremes that action scenes reach, and it explores the commercial and social function of the genre. The course also traces Action's historic reach and global diversity to include its significant precursors and transnational forms that Action cinema takes on.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cinema and Sensation I: Action/Spectacle (formerly INI222H1)

courses.name: Cinema and Sensation II: Sex (formerly INI223H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Erotic images and sounds have long featured in filmic pleasure and, for just as long, excited controversy. This course examines how sex is articulated on screen and how its regulation suggests broader themes and ideas. Topics include: obscenity laws and the history of film censorship, the eroticized aspects of conventional movies, art cinema, and "adult" erotic films.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cinema and Sensation II: Sex (formerly INI223H1)

courses.name: Selected Topics in Cinema Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on selected topics in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "New Media."
cmCourseInfo.title: Selected Topics in Cinema Studies

courses.name: Film Cultures II: Politics and Global Media (formerly INI214Y1 Film Theory/ INI314Y1/ INI315Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines film theory and practice from the 1950s onward, and the impact of media change on earlier film cultures and aesthetics. Topics include: New Wave cinemas, the politicization of theory, spectatorship, counter-cinemas, transnational film and “Global Hollywood”, and media theory from the analog to the digital.
cmCourseInfo.title: Film Cultures II: Politics and Global Media (formerly INI214Y1 Film Theory/ INI314Y1/ INI315Y1)

courses.name: Documentary Film (formerly INI325Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Critical and historical survey of documentary practice, including cinema verité, ethnographic experiments, and various hybrid forms, with emphasis on the rhetorical, aesthetic, and political dimensions of the "art of record." Topics include: the filmmaker/subject/audience nexus; historiography, hagiography, and performance; and how emerging technology and new media platforms, evinced in the rise of documentary-based webdocs, i-docs, and webgames, affect the actual production and style of linear documentary, as well as impact earlier models of documentary exhibition, distribution, and viewer engagement alike.
cmCourseInfo.title: Documentary Film (formerly INI325Y1)

courses.name: Feminist Approaches to Cinema (formerly INI323Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Gender politics of feminist film culture since the 1970s. Topics include: apparatus theory and its legacy, models of spectatorship, feminist historiography, the cinematic (re)production of identity, the relationship between social movements and cinema, "postfeminism."
cmCourseInfo.title: Feminist Approaches to Cinema (formerly INI323Y1)

courses.name: The Origins of the Animation Industry, 1900-1950: A Technosocial History (formerly INI383H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to early animation, considering its vaudeville roots, industrialization, emerging aesthetics, and representational tropes. Examination of the early corpus of animation from 1900-1950, and in-depth study of the artistic, social, and cultural milieux from which animation derived.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Origins of the Animation Industry, 1900-1950: A Technosocial History (formerly INI383H1)

courses.name: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice (formerly INI397H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "History of Cinematography," and "Everyday Life in the Digital Age."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice (formerly INI397H1)

courses.name: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice (formerly INI397H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "History of Cinematography," and "Everyday Life in the Digital Age."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice (formerly INI397H1)

courses.name: Screenwriting (formerly INI388H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Students will develop screenwriting skills under the guidance of a renowned screenwriter-in-residence through a combination of writing workshops and individual consultations. Like the course, the appointment of the Universal Screenwriter-in-Residence occurs biannually.
cmCourseInfo.title: Screenwriting (formerly INI388H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, and two additional Cinema Studies full-course equivalents

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For ‘E’ indicator Cinema Studies Courses: Contact the Undergraduate Assistant, 416-978-8571, cinema.studies@utoronto.ca .

courses.name: Issues in Film Authorship II (formerly INI375H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced study of issues in film authorship through intensive examination of one or more major filmmakers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Issues in Film Authorship II (formerly INI375H1)

courses.name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "Cinema and Intermediality."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism

courses.name: Critical Writing on Film (formerly INI384H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The practice of film criticism: studies of examples of journalistic and scholarly critical writing, practical sessions of process writing, and collaborative editing. Course includes regular film screenings.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Writing on Film (formerly INI384H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: CIN105Y1 and one additional Cinema Studies full-course equivalent/ permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For ‘E’ indicator Cinema Studies Courses: Contact the Undergraduate Assistant, 416-978-8571, cinema.studies@utoronto.ca .

courses.name: American Filmmaking in the Studio Era (formerly INI324Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Industrial, economic, ideological, and aesthetic dimensions of the American studio era.
cmCourseInfo.title: American Filmmaking in the Studio Era (formerly INI324Y1)

courses.name: Chinese Cinemas (formerly INI390Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of Chinese films in their three post-World War II production centres: The People's Republic of China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Commercial, political, and aesthetic trends; international reception; major auteurs and genres. Directors include Tsui Hark, Chen Kaige, Zang Yimou, Edward Yang, John Woo, and Wong Kar-Wai.
cmCourseInfo.title: Chinese Cinemas (formerly INI390Y1)

courses.name: Aspects of a National Cinema (formerly INI381H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth treatment of a national cinema. Past courses include: "British Cinema," "Australian and New Zealand Cinema," and "The Other Europe."
cmCourseInfo.title: Aspects of a National Cinema (formerly INI381H1)

courses.name: Advanced Study in Genre and Modes (formerly INI460H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: See course description for CIN412H1 listed below.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Study in Genre and Modes (formerly INI460H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least ten full-course equivalents, including CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, CIN301Y1/ permission of instructor

courses.name: Advanced Study in Theory and Criticism (formerly INI468H1)

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Expanded Cinema: Moving Images in the Gallery

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced study of select approaches to film theory and criticism. Past seminars include: “Corporeality and the Cinema,” “The Cinematic City: Urban Spaces in Film,” “Sound and Music in Film,”  “Expanded Cinema,” “Digital Cinema,” and "Cinema and Architecture: Scenes, Screens, Studios."
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Study in Theory and Criticism (formerly INI468H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least ten full-course equivalents, including CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, CIN301Y1/ permission of instructor

Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
